Density functional theory (DFT) is a theoretical framework used in physics and chemistry to study the behavior of many-electron systems, particularly atoms, molecules, and solids. It is a computational method that is used to predict the properties of a system based on the density of the particles that make it up, rather than the wave function of those particles.

In DFT, the total energy of a system is expressed as a functional of the density of the system. This allows researchers to calculate the electronic structure and other properties of a system using computational methods, such as quantum chemistry software packages.

DFT is a very powerful tool that has been widely used in a variety of fields, including materials science, chemistry, and physics, to study the properties of systems at the atomic and molecular level. It has been particularly successful in predicting the structural, electronic, and thermodynamic properties of solids, and has played a key role in the development of many modern materials, including metals, semiconductors, and polymers.
